awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: How Science Fieldwork Experiences Impact Undergraduate Students' STEM Academic and Career Decisions
awd_abstract_narration:
The representation of women in the earth, atmospheric, and ocean sciences workforce is significantly lower than that of female undergraduate students majoring in these disciplines.  This underrepresentation limits the available role models for female undergraduate and graduate students, and female scientists working in industry.  It is critical to understand the factors that may influence why male or female undergraduate students pursue the STEM workforce or not.  Advancing a diverse and technically competent STEM workforce is critical to the progress of science and the health, prosperity and welfare of our nation.
 
This project team is investigating the contextual components of social cognitive career theory to explore how male and female undergraduate geology students successfully navigate scientific fieldwork experiences as they pursue academic and career paths.  More specifically, knowledge will be advanced about how social, cultural, educational, and identity variables interact with each other during and after fieldwork to affect transitions from undergraduate education to graduate education or industry employment.  Mixed methods research will include the collection and analysis of survey and interview data.  Results will be examined to advance knowledge about how and why STEM undergraduates who do field work pursue STEM careers, and to inform future educational research on social cognitive career theory as it applies to STEM disciplines. 
 
This research is supported by NSF's EHR Core Research (ECR) program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field. Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring: STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development. The program supports the accumulation of robust evidence to inform efforts to understand, build theory to explain, and suggest intervention and innovations to address persistent challenges in STEM interest, education, learning, and participation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to understand how social, cultural, educational, and personal factors associated with undergraduate field courses influence undergraduate students, particularly women and students from marginalized identities.

 

Undergraduate geoscience field courses impact marginalized students’ self-efficacy. This project contributed new knowledge about how undergraduate geology field experiences negatively and positively impacted marginalized students’ self-efficacy and which types of self-efficacy are impacted. Self-efficacy is an important factor associated with marginalized students’ persistence in a career path. This project found that geoscience field course experiences impacted marginalized students’ academic, social, and physical self-efficacy. Negative experiences during field courses, including gender discrimination and crude sexual jokes, decreased marginalized students’ self-efficacy. Positive experiences like earning good grades and working in teams increased marginalized students’ self-efficacy. Marginalized students intended to persist in a geoscience career path despite some decreased self-efficacy caused by negative experiences in geoscience field courses.

 

Sexism was reported frequently by faculty and students who participated in in-person undergraduate geoscience field courses. Sixty-five percent of instructors and undergraduate students reported encountering sexism directed toward women during in-person, undergraduate geoscience summer field courses. This finding provides insight into the prevalence of sexism in summer field courses. However, only 27% of instructors and undergraduate students reported encountering sexism directed toward women during virtual, undergraduate geoscience summer field courses.  The lower percentage of participants reporting sexism in virtual field courses could be due to less frequent interactions during virtual field courses.  


Sexism is normalized in in-person undergraduate geoscience field courses. This project contributed new knowledge about sexism directed toward women encountered in undergraduate in-person geoscience field courses. The project identified the types of sexism encountered including Physical Sexual Harassment; Sexist Comments and Jokes; Women Treated or Perceived as Less Competent; Exclusionary Actions, Beliefs, and Climate; Women Treated or Perceived as Less Likable. Identifying the types of sexism that occur in geology field courses contributes to a growing knowledge base of the hostile environment in science field experiences. 


Instructors and students described sexism behaviors and beliefs as typical, frequently occurring, disregarded, and justified by other instructors and students. These ways of describing sexism indicate that sexism is normalized in geology field courses.  This is a critical finding because normalized sexism was found across multiple field courses led by different universities, suggesting that normalized sexism in field settings may be a cultural norm in the geoscience discipline more broadly. 


Policies and training do not reduce sexism in in-person undergraduate geoscience field courses. Federal and university policies prohibiting sexist behaviors in the geoscience field courses studied in this. However, sexism still occurred. The policies did not seem to influence the occurrence of sexist experiences in geoscience field courses. Training on gender discrimination and harassment largely did not influence the occurrence of sexist experiences. Existing policies and training may be insufficient to disrupt normalized sexism in geoscience field courses. 


Transformative experience in fieldwork education related to sexism and minoritized identities. Geologic fieldwork is widely considered to be transformative for undergraduate geology students. However, the mechanisms in which students undergo the transformation and the outcomes of these transformations are not well understood. Data collected in this project show that fieldwork experiences can play a critical role in developing students' science identity, sense of belonging, influencing academic and career decisions, and persistence in geology. While fieldwork can lead to many positive outcomes for students, if those fieldwork experiences are negative, they may drive students away from further study in geology, particularly for students with minoritized identities. We investigated the factors that affect a student's undergoing of a transformative experience within a geological field setting through mixed methods. A combined theory of transformative experience that merges elements of educational and philosophical conceptions appears useful in understanding outcomes from field camp experiences. This lens will provide insights into why students who are women, minorities, or who have other minoritized identities have differential field camp experiences that become associated with academic and career persistence outcomes as we move toward an explanatory framework that shows how the same field experiences can generate such disparate outcomes for students.
